question.title: Netty 4 Outbound Message Handler Closing Connection

node.contents: I'm experimenting with a custom outbound message handler in Netty 4 and cannot seem to get it to work. The handler just logs a statement and is added toward the bottom of the channel pipeline. My understanding is that these handlers are invoked from the bottom up, in order, once a write operation is issued. The idea with the custom handler was that it would be executed prior to any other outbound message handlers.

astNode.text: I'm experimenting with a custom outbound message handler in Netty 4 and cannot seem to get it to work. The handler just logs a statement and is added toward the bottom of the channel pipeline. My understanding is that these handlers are invoked from the bottom up, in order, once a write operation is issued. The idea with the custom handler was that it would be executed prior to any other outbound message handlers.

node.contents: Unfortunately, when I add this logging handler to the pipeline, I see the log statement but then Netty seems to immediately close the connection. Here's my channel initializer and outbound handler code.

astNode.text: Unfortunately, when I add this logging handler to the pipeline, I see the log statement but then Netty seems to immediately close the connection. Here's my channel initializer and outbound handler code.

elements.contents: public class HttpOutboundHandler extends ChannelOutboundMessageHandlerAdapter<DefaultFullHttpResponse> { private static final Logger logger = LoggerFactory.getLogger(HttpOutboundHandler.class); @Override public void flush(ChannelHandlerContext context, DefaultFullHttpResponse response) throws Exception { logger.debug("Executing outbound handler."); } }

units.rawText: public class HttpOutboundHandler extends ChannelOutboundMessageHandlerAdapter<DefaultFullHttpResponse> { private static final Logger logger = LoggerFactory.getLogger(HttpOutboundHandler.class); @Override public void flush(ChannelHandlerContext context, DefaultFullHttpResponse response) throws Exception { logger.debug("Executing outbound handler."); } }

elements.contents: @Override protected void initChannel(SocketChannel socketChannel) throws Exception { pipeline.addLast("encoder", new HttpResponseEncoder()); pipeline.addLast("decoder", new HttpRequestDecoder()); pipeline.addLast("aggregator", new HttpObjectAggregator(1048576); pipeline.addLast("compressor", new HttpContentCompressor(gzipLevel)); pipeline.addLast("outboundHandler", outboundHandler); pipeline.addLast(eventExecutorGroup, "inboundHandler", inboundHandler); }

units.rawText: @Override protected void initChannel(SocketChannel socketChannel) throws Exception { pipeline.addLast("encoder", new HttpResponseEncoder()); pipeline.addLast("decoder", new HttpRequestDecoder()); pipeline.addLast("aggregator", new HttpObjectAggregator(1048576); pipeline.addLast("compressor", new HttpContentCompressor(gzipLevel)); pipeline.addLast("outboundHandler", outboundHandler); pipeline.addLast(eventExecutorGroup, "inboundHandler", inboundHandler); }

node.contents: Answering my own question in case anyone else finds this.

astNode.text: Answering my own question in case anyone else finds this.

node.contents: It turns out I needed to add the message to the next outbound message buffer (which I believe has the effect of passing it to the next handler in the chain). I also needed to retain the message. The updated code now looks like...
